article:
The US democracy is strong enough to survive Donald Trump, says economic historian Harold James. He sees the pandemic as a decisive turning point for the whole country.

Harold James is an economic historian. He is a Professor
of History at Princeton University as well as the university's
Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. In 2004 he was awarded the Helmut Schmidt Prize for Economic History, 
and in 2005 the Ludwig Erhard Prize for writing about economics.
Lesen Sie dieses Interview auf Deutsch.
ZEIT ONLINE: Professor James, Donald Trump is lagging far behind in
the polls and all signs point to him losing the election. Many argue
that his mismanagement of the pandemic is the primary reason for his
struggles. Would you agree?
Harold James:
Yes, and I think it’s not atypical. What is happening in the United States at the moment has happened before. Take President George W. Bush, for example: His handling of the Iraq war was terrible, but
what really switched the view of the voters was his bad management of
Hurricane Katrina and the devastation of New Orleans.
ZEIT
ONLINE: Do you believe that without the pandemic, a Trump victory
would have been more likely?
James: There are only very few factors that have a significant impact on the
outcome of elections. One is the state of the economy. Before the
pandemic broke out, it certainly wasn't as marvelous as Trump likes
to portray, and he inherited the recovery from his predecessor Barack Obama. But in part due to the large stimulus provided by the Trump
administration, employment was growing, wages were rising, and growth
was stable. Without corona, all this might well have produced a
victory for Donald Trump.
ZEIT
ONLINE: Is the economy the only important factor for Trump voters?
James: When it comes to Donald Trump, there might be a little bit more at
play. He broke with the foreign policy consensus that the United States must be present around the world with its military. Barack Obama made
a similar promise; he at least pushed for a disengagement. But then,
he sent more troops into Afghanistan and became heavily involved in
the Middle East. Trump, on the other hand, delivered. His rhetoric
has been divisive, and the manner in which he alienated all kinds of
U.S. allies has been appalling, but he didn't start any foreign wars,
at least not any big wars.
ZEIT
ONLINE: His disrespect for the rule of law, the hollowing out of
democratic institutions: Don't those things matter to the average
voter?
James: Many Americans don’t see Donald Trump as a threat to the rule of
law. I think his activity wasn’t even very dramatic until recently.
But with his latest executive order, he is corroding the civil
service and putting his political appointees in positions where they
will be difficult to be dismissed in a new administration. Other
administrations in their dog days have done that in the past, but
Trump is doing it on a much bigger scale. And that is really pretty
terrifying. I do not deny that awful things have happened during the
last four years. Detained immigrants were treated terribly, just to
name one example. But not too many Americans care about that.
ZEIT
ONLINE: You don't see Trump as an autocratic president who is
skeptical of democracy?
James: Of course he is. But if you compare Donald Trump with the dictators
and autocrats he admires – people like Kim Jong Un or Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Viktor Orbán– you'll realize that it's not much more
than rhetoric. Trump is only performing fascism. 

ZEI
ONLINE: You see him as less of a threat to democracy than many argue?
James: Some people believe he is dismantling a system that was basically
designed in the 18th century. And this system obviously has its
limits when faced with 21st-century realities and someone like Donald
Trump in the White House. But I have to say, I am not convinced. The
American institutions are quite strong, democracy will survive Donald
Trump. If he loses the election, I think we will see a rebound to
some form of pre-Trump normality, at least on the political front.
ZEIT
ONLINE: How quickly will that happen?
James: We are obviously in a situation with a lot of uncertainty. It depends
on what Donald Trump does if he loses on Nov. 3. If it's close and if
the election is followed by a lot of violence, and if Trump refuses
to accept the result, then we would find ourselves in uncharted
waters.
ZEIT
ONLINE: And what happens if Trump does win the election?
James:
Some people who voted for Donald Trump in 2016 may have thought that
he would become more conventional and statesmanlike when in office,
and that the inherent dignity of the office would envelop him. Those
hopes were rapidly dashed, and it became clear that the new President
had embarked on a war against established institutions. In a similar
way, there is no reason now in 2020 to think that he will behave like
previous Republican presidents in their second term – Reagan or
George W. Bush – who came in as iconoclasts and ended up as much
more conventionally and internationally oriented leaders.
ZEIT
ONLINE: That sounds rather harmless. Some fear that America would be
virtually destroyed by a second term of Trump.
James:
There will certainly be very hard four years. We are likely to see a
continuation of the politics of rage, and a polarization that will
push the United States into bitter constitutional conflict –
especially as it is extremely unlikely, maybe even virtually impossible that
Trump’s party will take back the House of Representatives.
ZEIT
ONLINE: Donald Trump won in 2016 by a very narrow margin in a handful
of swing states. Should the voting system be reformed?
James: I hope that some aspects will be overhauled. In the United States,
the president is not elected by a popular vote, but by way of a
complicated system ending with the Electoral College ultimately
deciding who gets to move into the White House. It's conceivable to
me that we might have to transition to a system where the president
is elected the same way as in France. There, you know right at 8 p.m.
on election day who is the next president of the republic: The
candidate with the majority of votes.
ZEIT
ONLINE: Let's assume that Donald Trump leaves the White House
peacefully: The new president will find himself faced with enormous
challenges, from battling the pandemic and economic recession to
rising inequality and climate change. Can he be successful?
James: It will be very difficult. I would add the huge historical legacy of
racial division to your list of problems. Barack Obama made his political debut with a
speech in which he said there aren't red states and blue states, but
only a single country called the United States of America. Biden makes the same argument, but you need more
than nice words. Maybe in retrospect, one could critiquethe Obama
years by saying that there was a lot of rhetoric, but not much was
achieved.
ZEIT
ONLNE: Can you provide an example of what needs to change?
James:
The health and the education sectors are highly discriminatory. It
will be a real challenge tackling that. It requires a fundamental
rethinking of the institutions. But at this point, I am slightly
optimistic. New technologies and also the pandemic are forcing us to
rethink things and maybe abandon old dogmas. You can see the huge
transformative impact of the pandemic in Europe already: The European
Union spent 10 years discussing whether there should be common fiscal
policy and common debt, but nothing happened. Once the coronavirus
pandemic arrived, though, the EU made a big step forward.
ZEIT
ONINE: Are you in favor of a European-style, statutory
health-insurance scheme in the U.S.?
James:
Yes. The old American health-care system was based on the assumption
that people stay in the same job for most of their lives: Big
corporations like AT&T, IBM and Ford provided health care for
their employees. But we are now in a completely different, more
flexible world, so we need to come up with a different way to
organize health care.
ZEIT
ONLINE: You have compared the current situation in the United States
with the final years of the Soviet Union. Where are the parallels?
James: Both systems were produced by a revolution: one in 1776 and the other
in 1917. And later on, both systems had significant difficulties in
dealing with technical and economic change and they both gradually
lost their dominating positions in the world. For the Soviet Union,
the Chernobyl disaster may have been the most important turning
point, while for the U.S., it could be the pandemic. The Soviet Union
didn’t survive, but my hope is that the American system will prove
more resilient and can rebuild itself. Donald Trump didn’t provide
any kind of solutions here. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: How far-reaching will this rebuilding be?
James: It will be game changing. You can already see that the shift in
technology has accelerated during the pandemic. Tomorrow, I'm doing a
seminar in Cambridge, and on Friday, I'm doing a seminar in Basel. I
can do all that without having to travel. 

ZEIT
ONLINE: What does that mean for the next government?
James:
The administration should not simply prop up old, existing companies
that could be both costly and unproductive. The cruise industry, for
instance, doesn't have much of a future. Does it really make sense to
pay cruise operators to continue employing people? Or would it be
better to create incentives for the employees to do something
different? 

ZEIT
ONLINE: Wouldn't such a process create rising unemployment and
inequality?
James: You can indeed see inequality taking off during the pandemic. Many
people have lost their jobs and the very rich are apparently doing
quite well in this crisis. That poses a threat to American society.
The task for the next government will be to generate new
opportunities once we have overcome the current crisis. But that
doesn't mean locking them into dead-end jobs. That would simply be a
waste of all kinds of resources.
ZEIT
ONLINE: In other words, America needs a Green New Deal?
James: The USA needs to change – dramatically. And the transformation is going
to take a long time and will be very costly. That brings us back to
the Soviet analogy: It was a leap in the dark at the end of the
Soviet system. The U.S. today is in quite a similar situation. In the
last presidential debate, Joe Biden was asked about the future of the
oil industry under his presidency, and he answered honestly: In the
long term, there isn’t really a future for fossil fuels. But by
saying that, you alienate and frighten people in some of the key
states, like Pennsylvania, for example. 

ZEIT
ONLINE: They fear that their jobs will disappear.
James: Exactly, but that will happen no matter what. There are other things
these people can do. They could build the transmission cables
necessary for the green energy instead of building oil pipelines, for
example. Of course, we can't promise all people that they will get a
job in green technologies, but what we can predict is that the energy
saving technologies will produce a considerable amount of investment
and generate a substantial amount of employment.
ZEIT
ONLINE: Is Joe Biden the right person for the job?
James: Barack Obama was one of the most brilliant speakers in recent
American history. His speeches were very powerful and emotional, and
some people felt bound together. Others, though, felt threatened. Joe Biden, by contrast, doesn’t look threatening to anybody. He is a
familiar political figure, rooted in the old world of politics. So
maybe he is the right person for this huge transition. A great
majority of the American people want someone reassuring after all the
angry rhetoric of Donald Trump.
